elements.name: Hydrogen
elements.description: Hydrogen is the lightest element and the most abundant in the universe. First isolated by Henry Cavendish in 1766. Hydrogen (H, atomic mass 1.008) has a melting point of -259°C and a boiling point of -253°C. It was first discovered or isolated in 1766. It plays a significant role in modern industry, research, and practical applications across various fields.

elements.name: Helium
elements.description: Helium is a noble gas discovered in the Sun’s spectrum in 1868 and later isolated on Earth. Helium (He, atomic mass 4.002602) has a boiling point of -269°C. It was first discovered or isolated in 1868. It plays a significant role in modern industry, research, and practical applications across various fields.

elements.name: Lithium
elements.description: Lithium is a soft, silvery alkali metal used in batteries; isolated in 1817. Lithium (Li, atomic mass 6.94) has a melting point of 181°C and a boiling point of 1342°C. It was first discovered or isolated in 1817. It plays a significant role in modern industry, research, and practical applications across various fields.

elements.name: Beryllium
elements.description: Beryllium is a lightweight, stiff metal used in aerospace applications; discovered in 1798. Beryllium (Be, atomic mass 9.0121831) has a melting point of 1287°C and a boiling point of 2470°C. It was first discovered or isolated in 1798. It plays a significant role in modern industry, research, and practical applications across various fields.

elements.name: Boron
elements.description: Boron is a metalloid used in borosilicate glass and detergents; first isolated in 1808. Boron (B, atomic mass 10.81) has a melting point of 2075°C and a boiling point of 4000°C. It was first discovered or isolated in 1808. It plays a significant role in modern industry, research, and practical applications across various fields.

elements.name: Carbon
elements.description: Carbon is a fundamental element of life with allotropes like graphite and diamond; known since ancient times. Carbon (C, atomic mass 12.011) has a melting point of 3550°C and a boiling point of 4827°C. Its discovery dates back to ancient times or is not precisely recorded. It plays a significant role in modern industry, research, and practical applications across various fields.

elements.name: Nitrogen
elements.description: Nitrogen comprises most of Earth’s atmosphere; isolated by Daniel Rutherford in 1772. Nitrogen (N, atomic mass 14.007) has a melting point of -210°C and a boiling point of -196°C. It was first discovered or isolated in 1772. It plays a significant role in modern industry, research, and practical applications across various fields.

elements.name: Oxygen
elements.description: Oxygen is essential for respiration and combustion; discovered by Priestley and Scheele in the 1770s. Oxygen (O, atomic mass 15.999) has a melting point of -218°C and a boiling point of -183°C. It was first discovered or isolated in 1774. It plays a significant role in modern industry, research, and practical applications across various fields.

elements.name: Fluorine
elements.description: Fluorine is a highly reactive halogen used in fluoropolymers like Teflon; isolated by Moissan in 1886. Fluorine (F, atomic mass 18.998403163) has a melting point of -220°C and a boiling point of -188°C. It was first discovered or isolated in 1886. It plays a significant role in modern industry, research, and practical applications across various fields.

elements.name: Neon
elements.description: Neon is a noble gas used in neon signs and lighting; discovered in 1898. Neon (Ne, atomic mass 20.1797) has a melting point of -249°C and a boiling point of -246°C. It was first discovered or isolated in 1898. It plays a significant role in modern industry, research, and practical applications across various fields.

elements.name: Sodium
elements.description: Sodium is a highly reactive alkali metal essential in salts; known for centuries, isolated in the 19th century. Sodium (Na, atomic mass 22.98976928) has a melting point of 98°C and a boiling point of 883°C. Its discovery dates back to ancient times or is not precisely recorded. It plays a significant role in modern industry, research, and practical applications across various fields.

elements.name: Magnesium
elements.description: Magnesium is a light, strong metal used in alloys; identified in the mid-18th century. Magnesium (Mg, atomic mass 24.305) has a melting point of 650°C and a boiling point of 1090°C. It was first discovered or isolated in 1755. It plays a significant role in modern industry, research, and practical applications across various fields.

elements.description: Aluminum is a lightweight, corrosion-resistant metal widely used in packaging and aerospace; isolated in 1825. Aluminum (Al, atomic mass 26.9815385) has a melting point of 660°C and a boiling point of 2470°C. It was first discovered or isolated in 1825. It plays a significant role in modern industry, research, and practical applications across various fields.

It was first discovered or isolated in 1824. It plays a significant role in modern industry, research, and practical applications across various fields.

Phosphorus (P, atomic mass 30.973761998) has a melting point of 44°C and a boiling point of 280°C. It was first discovered or isolated in 1669. It plays a significant role in modern industry, research, and practical applications across various fields.

elements.name: Radium
elements.description: Radium is a radioactive alkaline earth metal discovered by the Curies; historic luminous paint use. Radium (Ra, atomic mass 226) has a melting point of 700°C and a boiling point of 1737°C. It was first discovered or isolated in 1898. It plays a significant role in modern industry, research, and practical applications across various fields.

elements.name: Actinium
elements.description: Actinium is a radioactive actinide discovered in 1899; used in research. Actinium (Ac, atomic mass 227) has a melting point of 1050°C and a boiling point of 3200°C. It was first discovered or isolated in 1899. It plays a significant role in modern industry, research, and practical applications across various fields.

elements.name: Thorium
elements.description: Thorium is a radioactive actinide investigated for nuclear fuel; identified in 1829. Thorium (Th, atomic mass 232.0377) has a melting point of 1750°C and a boiling point of 4820°C. It was first discovered or isolated in 1829. It plays a significant role in modern industry, research, and practical applications across various fields.

elements.name: Protactinium
elements.description: Protactinium is a scarce radioactive actinide discovered in 1913; used in research. Protactinium (Pa, atomic mass 231.03588) has a melting point of 1572°C and a boiling point of 4000°C. It was first discovered or isolated in 1913. It plays a significant role in modern industry, research, and practical applications across various fields.

elements.name: Uranium
elements.description: Uranium is a heavy radioactive element used in nuclear power and weapons; discovered in 1789. Uranium (U, atomic mass 238.02891) has a melting point of 1132°C and a boiling point of 4131°C. It was first discovered or isolated in 1789. It plays a significant role in modern industry, research, and practical applications across various fields.

elements.name: Neptunium
elements.description: Neptunium is the first transuranic element, synthesized in 1940; radioactive. Neptunium (Np, atomic mass 237) has a melting point of 644°C and a boiling point of 3902°C. It was first discovered or isolated in 1940. It plays a significant role in modern industry, research, and practical applications across various fields.

elements.name: Plutonium
elements.description: Plutonium is a radioactive actinide central to nuclear energy and weapons; first produced in 1940–41. Plutonium (Pu, atomic mass 244.0) has a melting point of 639°C and a boiling point of 3235°C. It was first discovered or isolated in 1940. It plays a significant role in modern industry, research, and practical applications across various fields.
